articles.headline: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
articles.snippet: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
articles.abstract: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAZBEGI CHECKPOINT, Georgia — Each day, a caravan of trucks stretches for miles along a mountain highway in Georgia, near the border with Russia. Each day, the line seems to get longer.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Hit Debt Limit on Thursday, Yellen Tells Congress
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department expects to begin taking “extraordinary measures” to continue paying the government’s obligations before what is expected to be a big fight to raise the borrowing cap.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department expects to begin taking “extraordinary measures” to continue paying the government’s obligations before what is expected to be a big fight to raise the borrowing cap.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned on Friday that she would have to begin employing “extraordinary measures” on Thursday to continue paying the nation’s bills if lawmakers did not act to raise the statutory debt limit and that her powers to delay a default could be exhausted by early June.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Goldman’s Pitch to the Little Guy Turns Costly, as Struggles Mount
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs will take a big hit from its ill-fated move into consumer banking, even as its other businesses weaken amid an economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs will take a big hit from its ill-fated move into consumer banking, even as its other businesses weaken amid an economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is paying for its misbegotten foray into consumer banking.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: ‘We Will Die for Brazil’: How a Far-Right Mob Tried to Oust Lula
articles.snippet: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how extremism is threatening Latin America’s largest democracy.
articles.abstract: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how extremism is threatening Latin America’s largest democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the bus made its way from Brazil’s agricultural heartland to the capital, Andrea Barth pulled out her phone to ask fellow passengers, one by one, what they intended to do once they arrived.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Simon Romero

articles.headline: ‘Based on a True Story’ (Except the Parts That Aren’t)
articles.snippet: The entertainment genre of historical drama is flourishing — and riddled with inaccuracies. The untrue parts are leading to more public spats and lawsuits.
articles.abstract: The entertainment genre of historical drama is flourishing — and riddled with inaccuracies. The untrue parts are leading to more public spats and lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The following stories are not based on real events. In fact, they’re completely made up — even though they’re meant to seem real.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
articles.snippet: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
articles.abstract: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — One morning in late October, Russian forces blocked off a street in downtown Kherson and surrounded a graceful old building with dozens of soldiers.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

articles.headline: Documents Inquiry Puts Spotlight on Biden’s Frenetic Last Days as Vice President
articles.snippet: The special counsel will have to reconstruct how a small number of classified documents made it to Mr. Biden’s home in Delaware and a private office in Washington.
articles.abstract: The special counsel will have to reconstruct how a small number of classified documents made it to Mr. Biden’s home in Delaware and a private office in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Those last days were a blur of phone calls, meetings, farewell events and visits to Ukraine and Switzerland. As he wrapped up his tenure as vice president in January 2017, Joseph R. Biden Jr. was packing in as much as he could.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: If Affirmative Action Ends, College Admissions May Be Changed Forever
articles.snippet: Schools may need to rethink everything, including recruitment, scholarships, standardized testing and alumni preferences.
articles.abstract: Schools may need to rethink everything, including recruitment, scholarships, standardized testing and alumni preferences.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Conn. — In 1964, hoping to erase its image as a privileged cloister for white rich families, Wesleyan University contacted 400 Black high school students from around the country to persuade them to apply.

articles.headline: Auburn Banned TikTok, and Students Can’t Stop Talking About It
articles.snippet: The school’s prohibition brings a geopolitical fight front and center for TikTok’s biggest fans: young Americans.
articles.abstract: The school’s prohibition brings a geopolitical fight front and center for TikTok’s biggest fans: young Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Destini Ambus, a senior at Auburn University in Alabama, was so surprised last month about a new ban of TikTok on state-owned devices and internet networks that she read the news alert about it aloud to her friends.

articles.headline: After a Burst of New Businesses, a Cooling Economy Intrudes
articles.snippet: The pandemic has brought a boom in entrepreneurship, but higher interest rates, a chill in venture capital and fears of recession now pose obstacles.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has brought a boom in entrepreneurship, but higher interest rates, a chill in venture capital and fears of recession now pose obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: An unexpected result of the pandemic era has been a surge in entrepreneurial activity. Since 2020, applications to start new businesses have skyrocketed, reversing a decades-long slump.

articles.headline: Driven by Election Deniers, This County Recounted 2020 Votes Last Week
articles.snippet: Lycoming County, Pa., officials were persuaded to conduct a 2020 recount, a three-day undertaking that showed almost no change, but left skeptics just as skeptical.
articles.abstract: Lycoming County, Pa., officials were persuaded to conduct a 2020 recount, a three-day undertaking that showed almost no change, but left skeptics just as skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa. — On the 797th day after the defeat of former President Donald J. Trump, a rural Pennsylvania county on Monday began a recount of ballots from Election Day 2020.

articles.headline: Dead, Alive or Devastated After Russian Strike on Apartments
articles.snippet: Rescue workers were still digging through the ruins of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.
articles.abstract: Rescue workers were still digging through the ruins of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 24 hours after a heavy-duty missile built to sink ships exploded  in a dense Ukrainian cityscape of homes and shops, the lights of emergency workers played across the rubble on Sunday, in search of life.
articles.byline: By Megan Specia and Nicole Tung

articles.headline: A Year After a Fiery Voting Rights Speech, Biden Delivers a More Muted Address
articles.snippet: On Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday, the president assured an audience at Ebenezer Baptist Church that its side in the struggle would, indeed, overcome someday.
articles.abstract: On Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday, the president assured an audience at Ebenezer Baptist Church that its side in the struggle would, indeed, overcome someday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When he came to the capital of the South to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. last year, President Biden delivered a call to nonviolent arms for voting rights, equating opponents to segregationists and vowing to rewrite Senate rules to defeat them. “I will not yield,” he declared. “I will not flinch.”

articles.headline: Price Gains Ease in Europe but Core Inflation Keeps Policymakers ‘Up at Night’
articles.snippet: Declines in overall inflation rates may bring comfort to consumers, but central bankers are still wary of drivers of persistently high prices.
articles.abstract: Declines in overall inflation rates may bring comfort to consumers, but central bankers are still wary of drivers of persistently high prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new year has brought Europe a little bit of good fortune. Unusually mild, even warm, weather has helped pull down natural gas prices after they soared for much of last year and sent inflation rates to record highs, upending the region’s economy.

articles.headline: Lawyers Barred by Madison Square Garden Found a Way Back In
articles.snippet: MSG Entertainment resorted to facial recognition technology to kick out legal foes, but some have undermined the ban using a law passed to protect theater critics in 1941.
articles.abstract: MSG Entertainment resorted to facial recognition technology to kick out legal foes, but some have undermined the ban using a law passed to protect theater critics in 1941.
articles.lead_paragraph: The problem with going to battle against thousands of lawyers is that it is likely to lead to lawsuits. And then the battle will inevitably head to their home turf.

articles.headline: China’s Latest Source of Unrest: Unpaid ‘Zero Covid’ Workers
articles.snippet: Companies that reaped windfalls helping the government implement strict ‘zero Covid’ controls are now struggling to pay and keep workers.
articles.abstract: Companies that reaped windfalls helping the government implement strict ‘zero Covid’ controls are now struggling to pay and keep workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: After China’s abrupt reversal of “zero Covid” restrictions, the nation’s vast machinery of virus surveillance and testing collapsed, even as infections and deaths surged. Now, the authorities face another problem: Angry pandemic-control workers demanding wages and jobs.
articles.byline: By David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Muyi Xiao

articles.headline: Skipped Showers, Paper Plates: An Arizona Suburb’s Water Is Cut Off
articles.snippet: Hundreds of homes outside the boundaries of Scottsdale can no longer get water from the city, so their owners are living a worst-case scenario of drought in the West.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of homes outside the boundaries of Scottsdale can no longer get water from the city, so their owners are living a worst-case scenario of drought in the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO VERDE, Ariz. — Joe McCue thought he had found a desert paradise when he bought one of the new stucco houses sprouting in the granite foothills of Rio Verde, Ariz. There were good schools, mountain views and cactus-spangled hiking trails out the back door.

articles.headline: Alarmed by A.I. Chatbots, Universities Start Revamping How They Teach
articles.snippet: With the rise of the popular new chatbot ChatGPT, colleges are restructuring some courses and taking preventive measures.
articles.abstract: With the rise of the popular new chatbot ChatGPT, colleges are restructuring some courses and taking preventive measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: While grading essays for his world religions course last month, Antony Aumann, a professor of philosophy at Northern Michigan University, read what he said was easily “the best paper in the class.” It explored the morality of burqa bans with clean paragraphs, fitting examples and rigorous arguments.

articles.headline: Mafia Boss Arrested in Italy After Eluding Capture for 30 Years
articles.snippet: Matteo Messina Denaro, who was sentenced in absentia for the 1992 murders of two prosecutors and other crimes, was apprehended at a Sicilian hospital.
articles.abstract: Matteo Messina Denaro, who was sentenced in absentia for the 1992 murders of two prosecutors and other crimes, was apprehended at a Sicilian hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Even by mafia standards, his crimes curdled the blood.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
